title: My dirtiest tactic: Maroons legends confess
text:
My dirtiest tactic: Queensland Maroons legends confess March 22, 2017 8:41pm Source: FOX SPORTS IT’S confession time on Queenslanders Only , and these Maroons legends have opened the closet doors and let their skeletons out. 
From sparring with Steve “Blocker” Roach to putting hits on unsuspecting New South Welshmen, these stories are brutal, and hilarious. 
Billy Moore, Mal Meninga, and Justin Hodges reveal their dirtiest on-field tactics. 
BILLY MOORE 
The “block play” that enraged Blocker, and our surprise sparring session 
“At the (North Sydney) Bears we had a play where the front guy would run into the defensive line, knock someone over and open up a hole, it’s called a block play. 
“We did that against the Tigers and put it on Steve Roach, I ran a block play and knocked him over, Greg Florimo ran through the hole ran 60 metres and scored. Billy Moore in action for North Sydney Bears.   
“To say Blocker (Roach) was upset would be an understatement. He jumped up, 120 kilos, went to town on me, split my ear, I got eight stitches. 
“Among all the chaos I looked up, the punches had stopped and there’s Pat Jarvis who had grabbed hold of Blocker, sorting him out. 
“I’ve jumped up and said ‘lucky you got in there Pat I was just about to get up’. 
“The next day Jarvis picked me up and took me to Newtown Police Boys Club to meet a guy called Johnny Lewis, the great (boxing trainer) Johnny Lewis. 
“He was fantastic, he said: ‘Come on in mate I’ll show you how to box, how to look after yourself’. He said come in and meet the boys. 
“I walked into the boxing ring and he goes here’s Jeff Fenech, triple world champion, I said, ‘How good’s that?’ He said here’s Jeff Harding, just beat Dennis Andries, world champion. 
“Then (Lewis) said wait on there’s someone else, a bigger bloke, he’s more famous ... and I thought, ‘Who could be more famous than a triple world champion and a world champion?’ 
“He goes, ‘Here he is, it’s Steve Roach, he beat you up yesterday.’” 
Ben Ikin, Nathan Ryan and Ben Glover examine Jason Taylor’s sacking at the Wests Tigers and how it impacts the club and its roster going forward.

MAL MENINGA 
Why I put a hit on Michael O’Connor 
It was 1991 and the State of Origin series was squared at one win apiece. 
NSW centre Michael O’Connor has slotted a sidelined conversion to steal victory from Queensland in Origin II, and Meninga wasn’t going to let it happen again. 
He rushed out of the defensive line to smash O'Connor early in game three, then followed it up with a wild arm to the head of his opposition centre. 
“I was a very fair player in my time, played fair but hard. 
“One moment I regret now — well I don’t regret it — was in an Origin series in 1991. 
“The series was 1-all, Wally (Lewis) has come out before the game and told all us players it was his last game. Mal Meninga’s statue meets Mal Meninga.   
“Last game, playing at Lang Park in a decider, so we got all emotional about it, and because of that we wanted to send him out a winner. 
“(O’Connor) was one of their great players, he kicked a goal right from the sideline in the dying seconds of game two that won them the game. 
“We could do those (hits) in those days, that was Origin, that was the emotional charge of Origin. 
“I would’ve been suspended today.” 
JUSTIN HODGES 
How I shook off a bad game, and why NSW hated it 
“For me it was about being aggressive, that’s what Origin football is about. 
“Sometimes you get into a game and you’re not feeling as great, you’re not getting the ball, so my thing was always my aggression in the tackle trying to lift my teammates. 
“There’s times there where you have to, especially in the Origin arena. 
“If you can win the battle over your opposite player physically and mentally you’re going a long way toward your team winning, and that’s what it takes sometimes. Justin Hodges gets physical with Aaron Woods.   
“Sometimes I’d be standing out there not getting the ball, so you have to make an impact in one way or another to inspire your teammates, and my way was always getting down there and being aggressive. If the fullback or winger got the ball put him on the ground and put his head into the ground. 
“That’s what you want, you’re putting fear in the opposition.” 
Hodges’ former Queensland coach Mal Meninga revealed his star centre’s aggression was often a tactic employed by the team. 
“ When I was coaching Origin we knew if Justin was aggressive, and if Greg (Inglis) was aggressive, the two centres ... the team was in good stead.”
